title: 113_hr1582
content: The "Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2013" prohibits the Environmental Protection Agency from finalizing energy-related rules estimated to cost over $1 billion if they will have significant adverse effects on the economy. Prior reports and determinations are required before such rules can be promulgated. Before finalizing any energy-related rule estimated to cost over $1 billion, the EPA must report to Congress with details including the rule, costs, benefits, and uncertainties. Before finalizing any energy-related rule estimated to cost over $1 billion, the EPA must report to Congress with details including the rule, costs, benefits, and uncertainties. The report must also include an estimate of the increases in energy prices, such as gasoline or electricity prices for consumers, that may result from the rule. Additionally, the report must certify that all data and documents used in developing the estimates have been preserved and are available for public review on the Agency's website, while ensuring confidentiality of sensitive information. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with relevant agencies, will analyze the potential impacts of the rule on energy prices for consumers, employment effects, and fuel diversity. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with relevant agencies, will analyze the potential impacts of the rule on energy prices for consumers, employment effects, and fuel diversity. Any adverse effects on energy supply, distribution, or use, including impacts on national electric reliability and increased use of foreign supplies, will also be considered. If adverse effects are determined, the Secretary will consult with other agencies to address these concerns. The Protection Agency, Commerce Secretary, Labor Secretary, and Small Business Administration Administrator will assess if a rule will have significant adverse economic effects. This includes considering costs, benefits, uncertainties, and impacts on economic indicators. The results of this assessment will be published. The Protection Agency, Commerce Secretary, Labor Secretary, and Small Business Administration Administrator will assess if a rule will have significant adverse economic effects and publish the results in the Federal Register. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "direct costs" and "indirect costs" are defined as per the Environmental Protection Agency's guidelines. An "energy-related rule that is estimated to cost more than $1 billion" refers to a rule regulating aspects of energy production, distribution, or use, with estimated costs exceeding $1 billion. The term "rule" as defined in section 551 of title 5, United States Code, applies to energy-related rules with direct and indirect costs exceeding $1 billion. Prohibition on using social cost of carbon in analysis. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency is prohibited from using the social cost of carbon in cost-benefit analysis for energy-related rules costing over $1 billion, unless authorized by Federal law. The social cost of carbon is defined as described in a specific technical document published by the Interagency Working Group on Social Cost of Carbon. The House of Representatives passed a bill on August 1, 2013, related to monetized damages from increased carbon dioxide emissions. Karen L. Haas attested to the bill.
